comments.commentBody: On one hand Trump is encouraging his followers to get out and vote.  On the other, he says the election is rigged.  If the election is rigged and is a foregone conclusion, why bother to vote?  That seems to be the mixed and confusing message is sending to his supporters.

The ONLY way to win as an outsider is if there is overwhelming turnout that cannot be denied. That is why Senator Sanders told his followers, the only way to win is to win so big that it can not be swept under the carpet when the FIX is in... That is how Obama won... He turned out millions of people, who normally do not vote or were voting for the first time. That is what Trump has to do. Political insiders and that ilk can only "lose" so many votes and flip so many machines.
Trump is nothing if not a bundle of mixed and confusing messages.

One white vote equates one vote. One black/brown/red/yellow/albino vote equals 3/5 vote. Anything else is fraud or rigged.

Many republicans believe this because America is a white-christian country and should only be governed by descendants of its white founders who fled Western Europe for political, economic or religious reasons.

i still dont really understand what happened in 2000, and most probably never will

it just didnt seem quite right, is all
@tuckerprguy: Those who  love everything appreciate nothing.

She didn’t do a public data dump because a lot of stuff that might have been embarrassing in a minor way and a lot of stuff that wouldn’t make a difference one way or another is mixed with enough stuff that is highly embarrassing and could be illegal that to release some but not all would cause all sorts of curiosity. The solution? Release nothing that isn’t pried from her cold, living hands – and then make sure it’s been sanitized.

This isn’t rocket science, guys. And she isn’t fooling anyone. Her core supporters want her elected REGARDLESS of what’s discovered in leaks. But if more IS revealed and it represents serious abuse of national secrets or other illegal activities, particularly with her foundation, those who are riding the fence but leaning to her could just abandon her, giving Trump a win.

But WikiLeaks does not offer a lesson for Sec. Clinton: she never had a choice about coming clean because she might be indicted if she did. She just had to take a chance on WikiLeaks – maybe it destroys her, maybe it doesn’t, because hackers either decide not to release what they have for their own reasons, or because they don’t have anything more.

This is classic GOP/FOX phony reason.  Suggest a vague, dark narrative, talk about what evidence there might be, offer no specifics or evidence (but pretend that anything that doesn't contradict your narrative is evidence of it), then quickly change the subject to the gullible or dishonest Democrats or liberals, or to the biased media .  .  .  It convinces no one, but I suppose it prevents the faithful from thinking objectively.

Y:

If his taxes concealed anything that was illegal, we would have heard from the IRS years ago. Yet eMailGate seeks to conceal patently illegal activities.

May, might, if...

Not a shred of evidence, Richard. For forty years now, your lot has been trying to destroy her -- and still no evidence.

Repeal the 2nd Amendment.

It was enacted when the country was young and didn't have a federal military like we have today...today we don't even need a "well-regulated militia" because for national defense, we far outspend everyone else on Earth...we're set in that regard.

Very few people actually need guns...they like them, they want them, they may feel emotionally better having them...but there is actually very little real need.

Have a mandatory buy-back program just like Australia. People say there's too many guns out there already, so there's nothing you can do...not true! Do the buy-back program, confiscate all weapons used in the execution of a crime, and very soon you can have a huge reduction in the number of guns in the country. Enact very stiff penalties for not complying with the buy-back program.

People will say "you can get killed driving a car" - true, but our society has been designed - from a physical point of view - around vehicle availability. You can't always walk the 7 miles to the mall or the grocery store...you need a car to operate in our society...but you don't need a gun.
Funny, the word 'car' doesn't appear in our constitution, nor does any other mode of transport.  But 'arms' does. See above advice to Roper.

"Private ownership of firearms" also does not appear in our Constitution.

Nor does "self-defense."
When the police force fails to protect citizens from lawlessness, the citizen must defend themselves in order to survive.  Thank you.
If you are in constant danger, a proper system would allow you to apply to a judicial authority for a proper permit for self-defense.
They are paying for their own pensions. The teachers have money deducted every paycheck that goes into the retirement fund.

I'm not a republican, but this kind of thinking is delusional. We can't ignore reality and the support for gun ownership that exists in this country.

1) Support for the 2nd amendment applying to all citizens of the United States is at around 73%. Repealing it is not going to happen anytime soon.
2) Even if it did happen, there are more guns than people in this country. How are you possibly going to confiscate them all? Besides the scores of guns slipping through the cracks, gun owners would probably not allow it to happen. There would be massive revolts.
3) Even if you managed to confiscate them from law abiding citizens, criminals would still have access to them.
4) Even if you did confiscate all guns, there's nothing to stop knucklehead, alcoholic, unstable type people from creating home made bombs or using knives to kill people.

Instead of going to the full extreme and scaring off gun owners from supporting *any* legislation that might improve the gun violence situation (which is exactly what this kind of rhetoric is doing), you should focus on trying to meet halfway and instead supporting much more reasonable legislation, such as stricter background checks and mental health evaluations.

The CDC's previous 'studies' on gun violence had proven to be questionable in their methodology that produced unreliable and contrived results and findings, which is why funding for further studies was cut-off.

These guys have answered their own questions. If 70% of the growth in entitlement programs is going to healthcare, maybe its time to take the profit out of it. Fee for service, $100,000 drugs, practitioners that make upwards of $500,000 because well, they're entitled, diagnostic tests that go for thousands, corporate executives raking in the dough, insurance companies skimming off the top 25%, shareholders reaping big stock returns, etc., etc., etc.

We put the clamps on other programs because be "don't have the money". Well, we don't have the money to spend 18% of GDP and growing on healthcare.

The other end of the picture is tax cuts. Remember those? Big corporations get away with paying very little in taxes, the super rich pay only 15%, trillions in earnings are sheltered overseas tax free, estate taxes are whittled down so vast fortunes can pass on that have never paid much in taxes while they were being accumulated, the tax code is loaded with breaks that profit many as Trump has shown us.

Then we have the never ending wars that started with a super tax cutter that we are still paying for where we fire $80,000 missiles at old pickup trucks, where we fly planes that cost $10,000 an hour to operate, etc., etc., etc.

Then we have unregulated banks that destroy trillions in wealth while they enrich themselves and are bailed out by the tax payer.

We already know how to fix the debt problem and so do the authors. They just don't have the guts to say it.
The motto of the American medical and pharmaceutical systems is, "Your money or your life."  Most other civilized countries have found a better way:  why can't we?

Europe has price limits on its drugs, feebfor service, and everything you have described.

The result? In the 1960s, before the widespread socialization of medicine in Europe, European companies were responsible for creating fifty eight percent of all new drugs. Now, they are responsible for creating less than half that number.

You see, it costs billions of dollars to develop new drugs. Similar to aircraft, where a single bad gamble floored Northrop Grumman, Douglas, Lockheeds commercial wing, saab, and half a dozen others, not being able to reap the benefits from your own creation leads to a dearth of good medicines to help people.

It is very easy to stand on a soapbox and preach to the skies about how unfair it all is. It is much harder to implement a working plan when you are utterly ignorant of the consequences of doing so.

This system is made to serve the rich.
It is simply corruption for all to see.

"Only 14 shootings involved assault rifles, illustrating their outsize role in the gun debate. Nearly every other assailant used a handgun. That is in line with a federal study that concluded that reviving a 1994 ban on assault weapons and ammunition feeding devices that hold more than 10 rounds would have a minimal impact, at best, on gun violence."

Tell that to the victims and their families & friends of those 14 deadly shootings. There is no conceivable rationale why military-style assault weapons should be legally available for sale to civilians. It's not an either/or choice between handguns and assault weapons when determining solutions how to lessen gun deaths in this country. Regulating legal and illegal ownership of both types of weapons needs to be thoughtfully addressed.

"Roper [to Sir Thomas More, in A Man For All Seasons]: So now you'd give the Devil benefit of law!
More: Yes. What would you do? Cut a great road through the law [read: Constitution] to get after the Devil?
Roper: I'd cut down every law in England to do that!
More: Oh? And when the last law was down, and the Devil turned round on you — where would you hide, Roper, the laws all being flat? This country's planted thick with laws from coast to coast — man's laws, not God's — and if you cut them down — and you're just the man to do it — d'you really think you could stand upright in the winds that would blow then? Yes, I'd give the Devil benefit of law, for my own safety's sake.
― Robert Bolt, A Man for All Seasons

Well, DG, you too seem just the man to do it. And BTW there are any number of rationales contra your assertion.

Angry:
Loved your quote. But DG is talking about adding laws to get at the devil, not cut them down. And no. he is not talking about eliminating ALL guns either, so perhaps we can skip that rhetorical step?

So, in the current political climate in the USA, there is no solution to gun violence. We are stuck living in an armed and dangerous society here. Doesn't matter what state you live in since it is so easy to cross state borders with guns. I  wonder how many of the guns used by ISIS and the Boko Haram came from the USA. Not only do we live in a violent gun society, we are an exporter of gun violence.
Right, guns don't kill people. Movies do. But American movies are released all over the planet - especially action movies - so why isn't every country awash in gun deaths?

We-the-People have the wrong focus. Led by the anti-weapons movement we call for laws to ban certain types of weapons, the ones that frighten us the most. The problem is that the person is the problem. The Second Amendment calls for and almost requires "A well-regulated militia..." People make up militias, piles of weapons make an arsenal and the amendment says nothing about arsenals.

To me it is time to resurrect the civil militia that answers to the government. Actually most states have state militias under a variety of names but all serve the same purpose - protect and defend the state from all enemies foreign and domestic.

If you want to keep and bear arms that should mean that you automatically become an associate member of the state militia and have mandatory screening, training, qualification and inspection of your private arsenal as well as being subject to the laws and discipline of the state militia. Use a weapon and you are subject to courts-martial and punishment. Also association will demonstrate who is, and isn't, qualified for certain types of weapons.

While the SCOTUS decision asserted the individual rights, it did not say that the states cannot require service in the state militia as part of their duties as defined in the Second Amendment. All rights have responsibilities.
The explanation is that terrorists don't have a lobby, gun manufacturers do. Thank the NRA.

@Richard Luettgen,
What do you think was in those missing e-mails? Filthy talk about about her groping some underling? Long, rambling adulation for Vladimir Putin? Nice comments about Kim Jong-un? An hilarious imitation of a disable person? A promise to refuse to concede the election if she ran for president and lost?

I have to admit that if she said those kinds of things I'd dump her in a heartbeat. And while I disagree with almost everything you say these days, I agree wholeheartedly with your last sentence.

Yes, the cover up itself is very often more damaging than what is covered up.

We will now be faced with years of a President doing this, about everything that comes up, over and over again, "she can be thin-skinned and secretive. As Neera Tanden, one of Mrs. Clinton’s closest advisers, put it in the emails, “She always sees herself bending to ‘their’ will when she hands over information.”"

It is wrong for the NYT to play into the campaign story that the Russians did it.

First, that is irrelevant to what is revealed, it is only an excuse why it ought to have remained hidden.

Second, the official position of the US government is that we don't know who did it. The story takes the Hillary campaign's version as truth, based I supposed on anonymous sources not even mentioned as anonymous.

Third, this paper gleefully published things released by Wikileaks, until they hurt Hillary. It did not focus before on where Wilileaks got the stuff, as if that were the real issue rather than the contents revealed. Only now.

Finally, there is quite a bit of interest in the things released so far. Not only does this paper not discuss them, this Editorial denies they even exist. That may serve Hillary, but not the readers and not the proper role of the NYT.

This all will come back to haunt, and sooner rather than later. It will be just months before we get "we did not vote for this."

This is the time, before we vote when our votes are still needed, that voters have their only power.
"...the official position of the US government is that we don't know who did it." NO it is not. The FBI has stated explicitly that it is Russia. You must read the NYT very selectively.
Sadly, we have absolutely no other choice.  She's the only credible candidate.

What is it about Mrs. Clinton that drives otherwise smart people (mostly men) to heights of lunacy.  Mr. Thomason:  1. It is very important who reveals the information and why.  If your enemy takes action to hurt you, it is the height of foolishness to take your enemy's side against your own country.  First, we deal with the enemy, then we work out our problems-- that's just common sense.  2.  It is, in fact, the official position of the US Government that Russia done it.  3. The Times has published numerous excerpts from the emails-- I've read them.  I've also read them in other publications.  There really is nothing damaging in the emails.  Unless you harbor some bizarre illusions about how government really works.  Strangely, Mr. Trump and Mr. Johnson are both millionaires-- but I'm sure they never sit behind closed doors and makes deals with the rich and powerful-- no way!  Guys just don't behave that way.  Women, though-- very sneaky.  Right, Mark?

Dale, actually most of what Gerry says are facts. As for the NRA, starting in the early 1970s they changed from focusing on gun training and safety to a focus on politics and gun rights. It's the pri-gun crowd that is unreasonable and not willing to talk about sensible gun control.

It's often reported that about 300,000,000 guns are circulating throughout the country. That figure suggests to me that we are a crazed people; that our national leaders (elected by us) are facilitating our slow national suicide. Nothing is more telling than the fact of our national gun-death total on our own soil being roughly the same as all American military deaths since the founding of the nation. We the People are doing this to ourselves.
Robert- Did you ever question if that number, 300M, is correct?  Or what it might be comprised of?  For example... 100M unusable curios & relics?  Do more research.  Be more informed.

300 million guns and less than 0.1% are used in a homicide or suicide in any given year.  Why does punishing the 99.9% of law abiding gun owners to prevent crime (including suicide as a crime) by 0.1% make any sense?  And since the majority (64% in this article) obtained their guns illegally, how will more laws make any difference?
The CDC can and are doing research into gun related crimes.

As a society, we dance around the giant elephant in the room. That being that we somehow think that we can have our cake and eat it too. We have succumbed to a gun lobby that has successfully skewed the intended meaning of the 2nd amendment to take on a persona and meaning WAY beyond common sense and the times. Yes, owning a gun is a RIGHT, but like ALL of our constitutional rights, there is no stipulation as to how those rights are guaranteed. We simply will never stop the senseless violence and butchery with the status quo and current tendency. More kids will die, more cops will die, more innocents will die. As a society, we are simply in perpetual denial of reason or logic and we are flat lying to ourselves that we can actually do something about it while continuing to enable and foment the problem. I don't know about you, "we the people", but I am tired and burnt out on the stupidity of the conversation which leads us nowhere. Change the conversation and we will change the outcome.

Jeremy:
And the original "intended meaning" of the 2nd Amendment was to allow certain States, particularly Virginia, to regain command and control and arming of their local militia, which they needed every day to enforce slavery.

The new Constitution had taken that ultimate control of militia from the States and given it to Congress. Virginia was determined to get it back. The 2nd was written in Virginia, not Philadelphia, by a Virginian, for the primary benefit of Virginians. The personal ownership of firearms was not even brought up for discussion at the meeting in Richmond where the 2nd was composed.

That "intended purpose" went away in 1865 when slavery was finally eliminated.

Occasionally a public figure shows the rest of the public, just what the south end of a northbound horse is like. Trump shows even under the most genteel circumstances, he is unable to control his rancor, his lack of propriety is there for ll to see. What he thinks of funny, is considered rude and insulting by people with manners and upbringing.

Oh, Hilary is not a comedian, yes she is serious and cerebral, and has been the target of smears and vitriol for many years, it probably precludes her making fun of herself, she probably fears some Trumpian will use it to denigrate her, as have the conservative cabal. Let us hope she will loosen up a bit one she is the Pres.

Trump has made a habit of ingratiating himself with those in power. Most of them have realized they have been used just to further his ambitions, and not because he actually likes them. He made himself persona non grata even among those who might still have some positive feelings about him. Getting booed at the Al Smith dinner is the ultimate insult, you can't get much lower.

It is not his political life he is fighting for, it is his economic life. He can not get any more financing from American banks, even the evil Carl Icahn wont lend to him. He has a fraud trial pending along with a RICO charge, then we will see what his source of income is.

A goth would make a better dinner companion than Trump. He was invited due to protocol, it won't happen again.
Don't forget the pending rape cahrges as well.

"It is not his political life he is fighting for, it is his economic life."

Thank you for saying this. I believe it to be true, and have wondered why I haven't seen it in the press yet. This entire campaign may have been launched for this very reason.
What a lovely and cultivated reply from the voice of the Al Smith dinner, thank you.

Joe Bob, What carnage are you talking about? The CDC totaled a count of 33,000 deaths by guns. 23,000 were suicides, and remember that Japan does not allow citizens to own guns yet their suicide rate is almost double the U.S.. So now we are at 10,000 deaths by guns, of which gang bangers that get their guns off the street account for 5,000 deaths, so now we are at 5,000 deaths, and 3,000 are from police shootings and the other 2,000 are actual premeditated killings and someone going nutso and shooting people. So where are these big numbers you are talking about? 36,000 people died in car accidents last year. Over 400,000 die from a medical malfunction, why do we not get rid of doctors? Your logic defies reason. Please answer me.

The intense focus on tearing down Trump ignores the speech that Hillary gave at the same dinner.

It is on YouTube. She got in some nasty zingers too. The race has really hit bottom.

Yet here in Hillary Campaign Central, all we hear is that Trump disrespected Hillary at a nice dinner.

Thank you for another chapter in the big book of false equivalence! It's quite obvious that her nastiness was far eclipsed by his. She could have gotten far nastier but restrained herself. That's presidential.

josh_barnes -- Thanks.

My agenda is what you and everyone else will be saying six months after Hillary is elected.

I want people to wake up in time, to limit her while she still can by limited by voters. Once she is in, she won't need votes, only money, and we know where she will get that and what she is willing to do to get it.
I have also followed Mark's comments for a couple of years and find that the fact that he became a Trump supporter does not surprise me!
